I watch their interviews, their public appearances, their social media videos. I learn everything there is to know about them, so that when I create my deepfake, it's not just a convincing imitation – it's an uncanny replica.

Once I have my target in my sights, I begin gathering materials. I collect hours of footage, audio recordings, and images. I use this material to train my AI algorithms, to teach them the subtleties of my target's voice, their facial expressions, their body language. I fine-tune my models, tweaking and adjusting until they can produce a deepfake that's almost indistinguishable from the real thing.

I learn what makes them tick, what pushes their buttons. And then, I use that knowledge to craft a deepfake that's tailored to their specific vulnerabilities. I create a narrative that's plausible, that's believable, that's designed to exploit their deepest fears and anxieties.

Of course, the key to a successful deepfake is to make it subtle. I don't want my creations to be too obvious, too over-the-top. I want them to be nuanced, to be believable. These are the things that make my deepfakes so convincing, so impactful.
